query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome [2009] or the effects of decontaminating clothing and equipment after entering caves to reduce the spread of the pathogen [2006]. Two studies, one in Canada and one in the USA, evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium for white-nose syndrome [2008]. The Canadian study found that treating little brown bats at the time of infection increased survival in a laboratory setting [2008]. The US study found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium in a mine increased survival for free-flying bats but not for caged bats [2008]. The Canadian study also found that the treatment reduced disease symptoms in a laboratory, but the US study found a similar severity of the disease in treated and untreated bats in a mine [2008].

query: To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments, what structures can be installed to help bats cross safely?
relevant_summary:
To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments on bats, several structures can be installed to help them cross safely. These include bat gantries or bridges, overpasses, and underpasses or culverts.

Studies on bat gantries in the UK and France have shown varied success. In two UK studies, it was found that fewer bats used the gantries than crossed the road at traffic height, with one gantry not being used at all [978]. A study in France on a temporary bat gantry observed its use by three bat species or species groups, but nearly half of the bats chose to cross the road at other locations [978].

Overpasses have also been evaluated as a solution. Research in Ireland and France indicated that while two or three bat species or species groups used overpasses, up to three-quarters of bats still crossed the road at traffic level or other nearby locations [977]. A UK study highlighted the importance of vegetation, finding that an overpass with planters was used by two-thirds of crossing bats, whereas an unvegetated overpass was not used at all [977]. In Australia, one study noted that an overpass supported the same number of bat species as nearby forest and bushland [977].

Underpasses and culverts are another option. Studies in Europe and Australia have shown that bats use these structures, but also continue to cross over the roads above them in varying proportions [976]. The effectiveness of underpasses can be influenced by their type, height, the width of the road, and the amount of forest and hedgerows in the surrounding area, as one French study found [976]. Furthermore, a study in Australia observed that bat species adapted to cluttered habitats were more likely to use small culverts and underpasses than species adapted to open or edge habitats [976].

query: How do different methods for restricting public access to bat hibernation sites, such as gates versus fences, compare in their effects on bat populations?
relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the USA found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence (999). Three of four before-and-after studies in the Netherlands, the USA, Spain and Turkey found more or similar numbers of bats in caves and a bunker after gates were installed to restrict public access, while one study found fewer bats (999). A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 Indiana bat colonies (999). However, one replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates (999). One study in the USA found that bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate over the entrance lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave (999). Two before-and-after studies in the USA and Spain found more bats within two caves after the size of the gated entrances were increased (999). A replicated, controlled, before-and-after and site comparison study in the USA found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed (999).

query: To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, what are the most effective operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities?
relevant_summary: To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, several operational adjustments to turbines can reduce bat fatalities. Ten of twelve studies found that increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities (1960). One study also found that slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds reduced bat fatalities (2939). Additionally, five of six studies showed that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’) led to fewer bat fatalities (970). Combining an increased cut-in speed with feathering has also been shown to be effective (1960, 970).

query: To protect bats from the impacts of mining operations, what actions can be taken during and after mine closure and reclamation?
relevant_summary:
Following mine closures, one action that can be taken is the installation and maintenance of gates at mine entrances to restrict public access (1963). Evidence on the effectiveness of this action is varied. For example, one study found that fewer bat species entered mines after gates were installed, and two studies in the USA and Australia found fewer bats in mines or at mine entrances after gates were installed (1963). In contrast, a study in the USA found that bat activity remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines (1963). Other studies have shown that bats circled more and entered mines less after gates were installed, and that some bats collided with gates (1963). In one study, 43 of 47 mines continued to be used 12 years after gates were installed, however bats abandoned four mines with ‘ladder’ design gates (1963).

Another action that could be taken is to retain access points for bats following mine closures, however, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of this action on bat populations (1962).

query: What are the most effective legislative actions for protecting bats and their habitats?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, legally protecting bat habitats has been evaluated in five studies across Europe and India (2045). In the UK, Daubenton's bat activity was higher in protected areas, and in Europe, common noctule bat activity was higher in protected forests (2045). Furthermore, two studies in France and India found overall higher bat activity and numbers in protected sites compared to unprotected ones (2045). One study in Spain showed that the distribution of 10 out of 11 bat species significantly overlapped with areas designated for their protection (2045). However, the impact on species richness is less clear. While one study in France noted a greater number of bat species in protected sites, two other studies in Europe and India found no difference in the number of species between protected and unprotected areas (2045). Additionally, one study in India found a similar composition of bat species in both protected and unprotected forest fragments (2045). For the action of introducing and enforcing legislation to control the hunting of bats, no studies were found that evaluated its effects on bat populations (984).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat habitats on bat populations. Four studies were in Europe and one was in India.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in India found that the composition of bat species was similar in protected forest and unprotected forest fragments.
Richness/diversity (2 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or paired sites studies in Europe and India found that the number of bat species did not differ between protected and unprotected forests or forest fragments. One replicated, site comparison study in France found that protected sites had a greater number of bat species than unprotected sites.

POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

query: For bat conservation related to transportation infrastructure, what are the documented benefits and limitations of providing or retaining roosts in bridges and culverts?
relevant_summary: One study in the USA found that creating spaces for roosting bats in road bridges to replace those lost during bridge works resulted in recolonization by bats in similar or greater numbers at four of eight sites (1967). Another study in Ireland found that a maternity colony of Daubenton’s bats continued to roost in a road bridge in similar numbers after crevices were retained during repair work (1966). However, a review in the USA found that while Yuma myotis and Mexican free-tailed bats recolonized most roosts in similar numbers after roosts were maintained during bridge replacement works, pallid bats did not return (1966). A separate review in the USA found that bat houses provided as alternative roosts during bridge replacement works were used by fewer Mexican free-tailed bats than the original roost at one site, and were not used by bats at all at three other sites (2942). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of excluding bats from roosts during maintenance work (2941) or changing the timing of maintenance work at road/railway bridges and culverts on bat populations (2940).

query: How does the evidence for managing existing hedgerows for bats compare to that for planting new ones?
relevant_summary: Two studies in the UK evaluated the effects of managing hedges for bats (1943). One of these studies found that hedges trimmed three or more years prior had a higher number of bat species and showed increased activity for two out of eight bat species or groups when compared to hedges trimmed in the previous winter (1943). However, another study found no difference in pipistrelle activity between hedges managed for wildlife under agri-environment schemes and those on conventional farms (1943). In contrast, no studies were found that assessed the effects of planting new hedges on bat populations (1942).

query: How does the evidence for legally protecting bat habitats compare to legally protecting bats during development activities?
relevant_summary:
Five studies assessed the effects of legally protecting bat habitats. One study in India found that bat species composition was similar in protected and unprotected forest fragments (2045). Two studies in Europe and India found no difference in the number of bat species between protected and unprotected forests, but one study in France found a greater number of bat species in protected sites (2045). Four studies looked at population responses. One UK study found higher activity of Daubenton’s bats over rivers in protected areas (2045). A European study found higher activity of common noctule bats in protected forests, but not for bats overall (2045). Two studies in France and India found higher overall bat activity and numbers of bats in protected sites (2045). One study in Spain showed that the distributions of 10 of 11 bat species overlapped with their designated protected areas more than by chance (2045).

Four UK-based studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bats during development. Two studies looked at human behavior, with one finding that the number of development licenses for bats in Scotland more than doubled in three years, and another finding that 81% of licensees did not conduct post-development monitoring (1935). Three studies looked at the impact on bat roosts. One review found that 68% of roosts were destroyed during licensed activities (1935). Two other studies found that between 5% and 67% of compensation roosts provided under license were used by bats (1935).

No studies were found that evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat species on bat populations (2037).

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of installing gates to restrict public access to subterranean bat roosts?
relevant_summary:
Following the installation of gates at mine entrances, a study in the USA found that 43 out of 47 mines continued to be used by bats 12 years later (1963). However, bats abandoned four mines that had 'ladder' design gates (1963). Some studies found that installing gates at mine entrances led to a decrease in the number of bats and bat species (1963). In one study, bat activity remained stable or increased at five out of seven gated mines but decreased at two of them (1963). Additionally, bats were observed to circle more at entrances and enter mines less frequently after gates were installed, with up to 7% of bats colliding with the gates in one study (1963).

For cave gates, some studies reported an increase or no change in the number of bats after installation, with one study showing population increases or reduced decline rates for 13 out of 20 bat colonies (999). Another study found that increasing the size of the gated entrances resulted in more bats (999). Conversely, one study documented fewer bats after gates were installed, and another found that hibernating bats in a gated cave lost more body mass compared to those in an unmodified cave (999). Similar to mine gates, bats were observed circling more and entering caves less after gate installation (999). The design of the gate influenced its effectiveness; fewer bats could pass through gates with narrowly spaced bars (999). When a steel gate at a cave was replaced with a fence, significantly more bats emerged from the cave (1991). However, a separate study found no difference in population growth or occupancy rates for bats in caves with or without fences or gates (1991).

query: In the agricultural sector, what are the observed effects of organic farming systems compared to conventional farming on bat populations?
relevant_summary:
A review of twelve studies comparing organic and conventional farming found that five of seven studies showed no difference in the number of bat species, while two studies found more bat species on organic farms [961]. In terms of bat abundance, five of nine studies found no difference in overall bat activity between organic and non-organic farms, while four studies reported higher activity on organic farms [961]. Additionally, two UK-based studies noted higher activity of Myotis species over water on organic farms, and one French study observed higher activity for two of three bat species over organic fields [961].

Related studies on chemical use showed that farms with low or no chemical inputs had different bat species compositions compared to high-input farms [2013]. Two studies also found a higher number of bat species on farms with reduced or no chemical/fertiliser use [2013]. Furthermore, two studies reported higher overall bat activity on farms with low chemical inputs [2013], and one study found that bats in chemical-free areas had higher body weights and better body condition [2013].

No studies were found that evaluated the effects of avoiding the use of antiparasitic drugs for livestock on bat populations [1948].

query: During building developments, what alternatives to bat exclusion have been studied to mitigate disturbance to roosts?
relevant_summary:
Three alternatives to bat exclusion have been studied to mitigate disturbance to roosts during building developments: creating alternative roosts, relocating access points, and retaining existing roosts (949, 946, 947). 

One review in the UK found that newly created bat boxes or lofts were four times less likely to be used by bats than roosts that were retained during development (949). Another review in the UK found that bats used two-thirds of retained and modified roosts after development, and retained roosts were more likely to be used than newly created roosts (947). One study in Ireland found similar numbers of brown long-eared bats using a roost within an attic after the existing access points were retained during renovations (947). In the UK, a replicated, before-and-after study discovered that four of nine bat roosts that were retained within developments were used as maternity colonies. Two of these colonies had similar or greater numbers of bats after the development took place (947). 

Eleven studies have evaluated the effectiveness of creating alternative bat roosts. Two replicated studies in the USA and UK found that bats did not use any of the alternative roosts provided in bat houses or a purpose-built bat wall after being excluded from buildings (949). However, three other studies in the USA and UK, and a review in the UK, found that bat boxes or bat lofts/barns were used by bats at 13-74% of development sites (949). Three of five before-and-after studies in Portugal, Ireland, Spain and the UK found that bat colonies used purpose-built roosts in higher or similar numbers after the original roosts were destroyed, while two studies found that bats used the purpose-built roosts in lower numbers (949).

Two studies have evaluated the effects of relocating access points to bat roosts. One before-and-after study in Ireland found that fewer brown long-eared bats used a roost after the access points were relocated, and no bats were observed flying through them (946). A UK-based before-and-after study found that few lesser horseshoe bats used an alternative access point with a ‘bend’ design to re-enter a roost, but the number of bats using the roost increased after an access point with a ‘straight’ design was installed (946).

query: What factors are associated with the successful use of artificial bat roosts by bats?
relevant_summary: Studies have found that a range of factors can be associated with the use of artificial bat roosts by different bat species. One study in Spain showed that modifying artificial roosts in buildings to reduce internal temperatures resulted in an increase in the number of bats using them (2052). In the UK, heated bat boxes were used by common pipistrelle bats at one of seven sites, but were not used by maternity colonies, and were not used at all by Natterer's bats in churches (2052). In Australia, a study found that 8 of 16 artificial hollows with two different entrance designs were used by long-eared bats (2047). The number of bats using an artificial hibernaculum in the UK increased over a period of nine years after it was built (2049). Artificial caves and hibernacula in the UK and Germany have been found to be used by up to four different bat species including brown long-eared bats (2049).

{
  "action_id": "999",
  "action_title": "Install and maintain cave gates to restrict public access",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of installing cave gates on bat populations. Six studies were in the USA and five studies were in Europe.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Three of four before-and-after studies (including one replicated study and one controlled study) in the Netherlands, the USA, Spain and Turkey found more or similar numbers of bats in caves and a bunker after gates were installed to restrict public access. The other study found fewer bats in caves after gates were installed. Two before-and-after studies in the USA and Spain found more bats within two caves after the size of the gated entrances were increased. One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 colonies of Indiana bat. One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Condition (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate over the entrance lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave.

BEHAVIOUR (5 STUDIES)   

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the occupancy rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Behaviour change (4 studies): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after and site comparison study in the USA found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed. One replicated study in the USA found that bats flew through gates with a funnel design more frequently than gates with a round bar or angle iron design. One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that fewer bats flew through cave gates when the spacing between horizontal bars was reduced. One before-and-after study in the USA found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence."

BEHAVIOUR (6 STUDIES)

query: What conservation actions can be implemented to combat the spread and impact of white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: Two studies investigated the effectiveness of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium to combat white-nose syndrome (2008). In a laboratory setting, treating little brown bats with this bacterium at the time of infection increased their survival and reduced disease symptoms (2008). However, treating them 21 days before infection resulted in worse symptoms (2008). In a separate study within a mine, the probiotic treatment increased the survival of free-flying little brown bats but did not have the same effect on caged bats (2008). The severity of white-nose syndrome in the caged bats was similar to that in untreated bats (2008). There were no studies found that assessed the effects of vaccinating bats against the white-nose syndrome pathogen or culling infected bats on bat populations (1011, 1012).

query: What design and placement factors influence the successful use of bat boxes by bats?
relevant_summary: Several factors influence the use of bat boxes by bats. In terms of design, bats were found to use black bat boxes more than grey, white, or wooden ones, and larger bat boxes had higher occupancy rates (1024). One study found that more bats occupied boxes with two compartments than one during the breeding season (1024). While one study found that resin bat boxes were occupied more quickly than wood boxes, another found that bats used both (1024). Concrete bat boxes had higher occupancy rates than wooden ones in one UK study, and in the USA, Indiana bats used rocket boxes more than wooden bat boxes or bark-mimic roosts (1024). Different bat box designs may be used by different species (1024). When it comes to placement, bat box orientation and the amount of sun exposure can affect occupancy, although one study found orientation did not have a significant effect (1024). The height of the box has also been shown to affect occupancy in some studies but not others (1024). Bat boxes on buildings had higher occupancy than those on trees (1024). Higher occupancy rates were found in farm forestry sites compared to native forest and in pine stands versus mixed deciduous stands (1024). Occupancy rates were also higher in areas where bats were already known to roost (1024). Furthermore, the more bat boxes that were installed across a site, the more likely they were to be occupied (1024). However, in cases where roosts were destroyed, newly built bat boxes or lofts were four times less likely to be used by returning bats than roosts that were retained during development (949). In two studies, bats did not use any of the alternative roosts provided after being excluded from buildings (949).

Different bat box designs may be used by different species (1024). When it comes to placement, bat box orientation and the amount of sun exposure can affect occupancy, although one study found orientation did not have a significant effect (1024). The height of the box has also been shown to affect occupancy in some studies but not others (1024). Bat boxes on buildings had higher occupancy than those on trees (1024). Higher occupancy rates were found in farm forestry sites compared to native forest and in pine stands versus mixed deciduous stands (1024). Occupancy rates were also higher in areas where bats were already known to roost (1024). Furthermore, the more bat boxes that were installed across a site, the more likely they were to be occupied (1024). However, in cases where roosts were destroyed, newly built bat boxes or lofts were four times less likely to be used by returning bats than roosts that were retained during development (949). In two studies, bats did not use any of the alternative roosts provided after being excluded from buildings (949).","action_ids":["1024","949"],"query":"What design and placement factors influence the successful use of bat boxes by bats?"}
